content.question: A particle moves in the <math alttext="x y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mspace></mspace><mi>y</mi></math>-plane so that its position at any time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> is given by the parametric equations <math alttext="x of t equals, t squared, minus t cubed" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>3</mn></msup></math> and <math alttext="y of t equals, 9 minus 6, t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>t</mi></math>. What is the speed of the particle at time <math alttext="t equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></math> ?

unit.text: 9: Parametric Equations, Polar Coordinates, and Vector-Valued Functions

topic.text: 9.6: (BC ONLY) Solving Motion Problems Using Parametric and Vector-Valued Functions

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
